awd_titl_txt: NSF SII Planning: National Center for Spectrum Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is a planning grant for the Spectrum Innovation Initiative:  National Center for Wireless Spectrum Research (SII-Center).  The focus of a spectrum research SII-Center goes beyond 5G, IoT, and other existing or forthcoming systems and technologies to chart out a trajectory to ensure United States leadership in future wireless technologies, systems, and applications in science and engineering through the efficient use and sharing of the radio spectrum. This project includes the planning activities needed to envision and articulate a National Spectrum Innovation Center (the “Center”), a multidisciplinary, multi-institution research and development collaboration led by Texas A&M University. The Center’s vision is to serve as a national hub for research, education, policy, and public outreach needed to assure the on-demand availability of dependable, affordable, high-quality spectrum access to all users. Research and technology development will be necessary to achieving the Center vision, but it will not be sufficient. Implementing a radical reshaping of spectrum access and utilization will also require new economic models and thoughtful changes in policy and regulation. It will demand changes in higher education curriculum and pedagogy to support a future workforce capable of meeting the needs of industry and of maintaining and innovating an intelligent-spectrum infrastructure. And it will need to build public interest and awareness, as well as account for the ethical dimensions of such an ambitious undertaking.

This award outlines planning activities for a Center which is a multidisciplinary, multi-institution R&D collaboration led by Texas A&M University.  The proposed center is composed of four key working groups: Technology, Education, Outreach and Policy. The Center’s technical approach will leverage advances in materials and mathematics; high-frequency and digital communication technology platforms; artificial intelligence and deep machine learning; and analog and neuromorphic computing to develop technologies that can dynamically allocate spectrum in real time across multiple, simultaneous users. Intelligent spectrum management has the potential to dramatically increase the capacity and efficiency of use of the radio spectrum. Beneficiaries will be not only the major institutional stakeholders, but also ordinary citizens, including many in currently underserved populations, for whom affordable, high-speed wireless services could provide access to health care, education, and economic opportunity. Work done under the planning grant will position the proposed Center to be a major locus of national collaboration in spectrum-related research, education, policy, and public outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Effort

During this planning effort, activities took place to envision and articulate a National Center in Spectrum Innovation, a multidisciplinary, multi-institution R&D collaboration led by Texas A&M University. The Center?s articulated vision was to serve as a national hub for research, education, and policy needed to assure the on-demand availability of dependable, affordable, high-quality spectrum access to all users. The Center?s technical approach leveraged materials and applied mathematics advances, high-frequency and digital communication technology platforms, artificial intelligence and deep machine learning, and neuromorphic computing, among others, to develop technology concepts that can dynamically allocate spectrum in real-time across multiple, simultaneous users. Research and technology development were considered necessary to achieve the Center's vision, but it would not be sufficient. Implementing the proposed radical reshaping of spectrum access and utilization would require new economic models and thoughtful changes in policy and regulation. And it would demand changes in higher education curriculum and pedagogy to support a future workforce capable of meeting industry needs and maintaining and innovating an intelligent-spectrum infrastructure. The planning project had the following objectives: (1) designing an initial Center research agenda, (2) identifying Center partners and their roles, (3) understanding economic issues of particular relevance to the Center, such as infrastructure costs, pricing models, and return on investment, (4) mapping the current environment for spectrum policy and regulation, and (5) developing a more profound understanding of the interests and needs of user groups, including those currently underserved by wireless services and the digital technology in general. The eight-member Spectrum Innovation Center Planning Team managed activities under the planning grant. The team brought high-level expertise in relevant technical areas of science and engineering; economic modeling and analysis; federal science policy and regulation; STEM education and workforce; science communication and community engagement; and the needs of populations underserved by current wireless technologies. The Planning Team was chaired by Linda Katehi, Texas A&M University, who has extensive experience managing large, complex, high-risk/high-reward projects. Planning grant activities included a literature review, stakeholder workshops, topical commissioned papers, consultation with experts who have agreed to serve as project advisors, and outreach to potential partners.

Intellectual Merit

Effective sharing of the radio spectrum is constrained by: (1) interference between active and passive users when they operate in the same physical and electronic space, even when they use separate but adjacent frequency bands, (2) the inability of communication systems, at present, to identify the statistical characteristics of the spectrum in real-time so they can adjust their performance accordingly, and (3) the inability of present system architectures to learn from the system?s sensory electronic experiences and to use these experiences to optimize their performance within a given electronic network. Given these realities, the focus of the proposed Spectrum Innovation Center was centered on the ability to incorporate intelligence in the design of future communications systems and to develop the appropriate standard, policies, and economic models that will facilitate and sustain a high-quality, on-demand use of spectrum.

Broader Impacts

Multiple stakeholders?researchers, commercial technology developers, service providers, and the government?depend on the spectrum to collect data, create and sustain profitable businesses, and assure critical systems' smooth and secure operation. The ?smart spectrum? approach to spectrum management has the potential to dramatically increase the capacity and efficiency of the use of the radio spectrum. Beneficiaries will be not only the major institutional stakeholders but also ordinary citizens, including many in currently underserved populations, for whom affordable, high-speed wireless services provide access to health care, education, and economic opportunity. Work done under the planning grant proposed a Spectrum Innovation Center with a significant locus of national collaboration in spectrum-related research, education, and policy and community outreach.
